title: Four-star 2021 Marshall County guard Zion Harmon picks Western Kentucky
summary:

title: Following 2018 Shooting, Kentucky School District Receives $620,000 Grant For Security Improvements -- Campus Security & Life Safety
summary:
Following 2018 Shooting, Kentucky School District Receives $620,000 Grant For Security ImprovementsMarshall County High School, the site of a shooting that killed two students in 2018, has since received hundreds of thousands in grants for security systems and mental health therapists.
A Kentucky high school that was the site of a fatal shooting in 2018 will receive more than $620,000 in grant money to install a security camera system and upgrade its facilities, according to state justice and public safety officials.
The Jan. 23, 2018 shooting near Benton took the lives of two students and injured 18 others in the school, causing deep wounds within the close-knit community of just over 31,000 people.
He added: “We are grateful the Marshall County Board of Education received this critically important grant.
The school district has previously received grants to launch its “Marshall Strong Recovery Project” and hire mental health therapists at Marshall County High School, where the shooting took place.

title: Nurse says she was suspended after refusing to treat coronavirus patients without a mask
summary:
USA TODAYLOUISVILLE, Ky. – A nurse at a hospital in Kentucky said she was suspended for insubordination for refusing to treat COVID-19 patients when the hospital would not supply her with a protective respirator.
Kenyatta Ervin, 49, said she previously had health conditions like pneumonia and asthma and needs the protection of an N95 mask, which have been in short supply.
She said in an interview Monday that supervisors would give her only a surgical mask, a loose-fitting disposable device that isn’t sealed around the nose and mouth.
Until the change, CDC recommended that health care workers interacting with coronavirus patients or suspected cases wear N95 respirators, along with gowns, gloves and eye protectors.
She said the first day, March 26, she was given an N95 mask, but on her second day she received only a surgical mask.

title: Body found in Ohio River identified as Louisville, Ky. man
summary:
MCCRACKEN CO., Ky. (WSIL) -- The body of a man found in the Ohio River in 2018 has been identified as an 84-year-old from Louisville, Kentucky.
The body was discovered in the river near the Brookport Bridge on September 18, 2018.
Efforts by the Kentucky Medical Examiner’s Office, McCracken County Coroner’s Office, “NamUS” Regional Specialist Amy Dobbs, Louisville Metro Homicide/Missing Persons Unit, and McCracken County Sheriff’s Department Detective unit led to the discovery of the man's identity.
“These are cases that really stay with you,” said Amanda Melton, McCracken County Coroner.

title: Kentucky could ban driving with a cellphone in hand in 2020
summary:
LOUISVILLE, Ky. – In 2020, driving with a cellphone, or any communication device, in hand could be illegal.
Kentucky’s current law bans drivers from texting, emailing, and instant messaging, but Representative James Tipton says that’s not enough.
Certain emergency situations are the exception to the rule, such as reporting illegal activity or summoning medical attention.
Sergeant Josh Lawson, Public Affairs Commander for the Kentucky State Police, said using a cellphone while driving can be like drunk driving.
If the pre-filed bill becomes a law during the 2020 session, then the Bluegrass State will join 20 other U.S. states, along with Washington D.C., Puerto Rico, Guam and the U.S. Virgin Islands, to make driving with a cellphone in hand illegal.

title: Ironman Louisville cancels swimming portion to due dangerous algae blooms in Ohio River
summary:
LOUISVILLE, Ky. — (WHAS11)-The Ironman triathlon will be missing a primary piece when it kicks off on Sunday after Ironman and city officials decided to cancel the swimming portion of the event.
The Kentucky Division of Water and the Kentucky Department of Public Health issued a recreational public health advisory concerning the elevated harmful algal bloom (HAB) that are present in the Ohio River.
The HAB advisory indicated that algal toxins had been found at various locations along the river and that swimming, wading, and other water activities were not recommended in those areas.
Following the result of tests that were performed this week, Ironman and local city officials have determined that in the interest of athlete safety, it is necessary to cancel the swim portion of 2019 Ironman Louisville triathlon.

title: 10 Toxic ‘Forever Chemicals’ Found in Louisville, Ky., Tap Water
summary:
A sample of residential tap water in Louisville, Ky, contained 10 different compounds in the family of toxic fluorinated chemicals known as PFAS, according to laboratory tests commissioned by the Environmental Working Group.
The sample, taken in July from a home served by the Louisville Water Company, was tested by an accredited independent laboratory for 30 different PFAS chemicals.
The combined total for all PFAS tested in the Louisville sample was 45.2 ppt.
Expert studies say that PFAS exposure in drinking water should be limited to just 1 part per trillion, or ppt.
The highest level of any single PFAS detected in the EWG sample collected in Louisville was 22 ppt of a compound known as GenX.

An investigation is ongoing and "is not connected to the polling location," Ruoff said.

title: Real Monarchs Win USL Championship Title
summary:
LOUISVILLE, Kentucky (Sunday, November 17, 2019) – Real Monarchs SLC went on the road to secure a third-consecutive comeback win in the USL Championship Playoffs, topping the two-time defending champions, Louisville City FC, 3-1 to win the USL Championship title in front of a sold out crown of 7,025 at Lynn Stadium on the University of Louisville campus.
Louisville held nearly 65% of the first-half possession and outshot the Monarchs 6-5, but the Monarchs finished the half with five unanswered shots from the 25th minute on.
Both teams had chances to add to the scoreboard over the final 24 minutes, but Ochoa came up big to keep the two-goal advantage as the Monarchs sealed victory and the USL Championship title.
- The Monarchs win in the final ended Louisville City FC’s run of two-consecutive USL titles.
- The Monarchs played with seven players on loan from Real Salt Lake – GK David Ochoa, GK Andrew Putna, DF Erik Holt, MF Justin Portillo, MF Luke Mulholland, FW Tate Schmitt and FW Luis Arriaga.

title: Nick Richards steps up to lead Kentucky basketball to overtime win over Louisville
summary:
Louisville Courier JournalLEXINGTON – The split second between hitting the floor and the official's call might have been the most nerve-wracking moment of the day for Nick Richards in Kentucky's 78-70 overtime win over rival Louisville.
Should the official rule the play a blocking foul instead of a charge, Richards would have fouled out of the game.
Instead, Richards stayed in the game, eventually scoring seven consecutive points after Louisville had taken a lead in overtime to finish the victory with 13 points, 10 rebounds and 11 fouls drawn.
Louisville jumped out to an early 6-2 lead but did not score for the next six minutes as Kentucky clawed ahead with seven straight points.
Also: Dueling recruiting strategies on display as Kentucky-Louisville rivalry hits next stageWithout Richards' performance down the stretch, Kentucky might not have been able to make Louisville pay for those misses.

title: Louisville's low temperature Tuesday night will flirt with decades-old record
summary:
Courier JournalIn case you missed it: Snow flakes fell Monday night, and it was brutally cold Tuesday.
The low temperature for Tuesday night at Louisville Muhammad Ali International Airport is forecast to be 18 degrees, according to Louisville National Weather Service meteorologist Mark Jarvis.
That will approach a 33-year-old record — the lowest temperature on Nov. 12 ever was 16 degrees in 1986.
The cold will persist into Wednesday morning, as wind chill will make it feel like the temperature is in the low teens.
Wednesday night will be cloudy with a low of 26.

title: The nation's first live-action gaming experience to open in Louisville
summary:
LOUISVILLE, Ky. — Louisville is getting it's first live-action gaming experience.
The partnership with Lexington-based Breakout Games, Activate Games offers guests an active gaming experience located in a vibrant and high-tech 12,000 square-foot space off Hurstbourne Parkway in Louisville.
“As Kentucky natives engaged in the experiential entertainment industry, we’re thrilled to bring Activate Games to Louisville for the community to enjoy,” said Bryce Anderson, co-owner of Activate Games America.
Once inside, guests receive an electronic wristband that tracks high scores and progress, making Activate Games suitable for intense competition or a low-pressure gaming experience.
Those looking to be the first to experience Activate Games can now book online at www.activate.games.

title: For Louisville Offenders And Victims Alike, A New Label: ‘Public Nuisance’ - Kentucky Center for Investigative Reporting
summary:

title: Snow will hit Louisville sooner than expected. Here's what to expect Monday night
summary:
CLOSEStart stocking up on the hot chocolate, Louisville, and pull out the blankets stuffed in the back of your closet.
It began raining in Louisville Monday afternoon, and it will be followed soon by snow and record cold Tuesday.
The Louisville National Weather Service has issued a winter weather advisory for several areas in Kentucky, including Jefferson County, to go in effect Monday evening.
There is a 100% chance of rain and snow, according to the service.
The frigid temperatures Tuesday following Monday's rain and snow could possibly freeze roads and prove hazardous, the weather service says.

title: 43rd Old Louisville Holiday Home Tour will be Dec. 7-8 - Lane Report
summary:
LOUISVILLE, Ky. — Returning on the first full weekend in December, the Old Louisville Holiday Home Tour gives visitors a rare glimpse inside several beautiful Victorian-era private residences and historic buildings dressed in their holiday finery.
The tour is set to showcase the rich and diverse history of Historic Old Louisville during the Yuletide season.
The 43rd annual Old Louisville Holiday Home Tour will take place Saturday, Dec. 7 and Sunday, Dec. 8 from noon to 6 p.m. Each year it attracts thousands of visitors to Old Louisville to experience “One of the Great Places in America,” as named by the American Planning Association.
”For 43 years, Old Louisville has opened its doors during the holiday season with a festive and welcoming spirit,” said Susan Coleman Layman, Old Louisville Holiday Home Tour chair.
The Old Louisville Holiday Home Tour serves as the primary fundraiser for the Old Louisville Neighborhood Council, which preserves, protects and promotes the history and culture of Old Louisville.

title: 1 dead, 4 hurt after crash in Louisville
summary:
LOUISVILLE, Ky. (LEX 18) — One person has died and four have been injured following a crash on West Main Street in Louisville on Friday.
The crash happened shortly after 10 p.m., when police said a speeding Ford Mustang crashed into a Chrysler 200 at the intersection of 25th Street.
A passenger in the back seat of the Chrysler was pronounced dead at the hospital.
Louisville police are asking for information about the crash from possible witnesses.
If you saw this crash or know more details about the incident, call the Louisville Metro Police Department at (502) 574-7060.

title: Sunday's rainfall could break a more than 100-year-old record in Louisville
summary:
CLOSE Louisville received 1.93 inches of rain on Dec. 29, 1910.
Today, Louisville might get more than two inches of rain.
The Louisville area is on pace to receive more than two inches of rain by the end of Sunday, according to the Louisville National Weather Service, which has placed the Derby City under a flood watch.
That total would break a record — the most rainfall the Louisville area had previously experienced on any Dec. 29 was 1.93 inches in 1910, according to National Weather Service meteorologist Mark Jarvis.
As of early Sunday afternoon, the Louisville area had received roughly an inch of rain, Jarvis said.

title: A new restaurant and music lounge inspired by 'great vibes' is coming to Butchertown
summary:
CLOSEVibes Restaurant and Ultra Lounge will open by the end of December 2019 in Louisville's Butchertown.
(Photo: Courtesy of Allen Evans)A Louisville native is opening a restaurant and music lounge in Butchertown, inspired by "great vibes" in lounges in Manhattan.
By the end of December, Vibes Restaurant & Ultra Lounge will open in Butchertown at 1346 River Road, in what used to be a restaurant called Relish.
Owner Allen Evans said that Louisville is "highly underrated" in terms of entertainment and he wanted to fill a need.
More news: This Butchertown pub is shutting down after 2 yearsThe focus is on the music and keeping it fresh: One week Vibes might feature reggae, with Cuban music the next week and Asian techno the week after that.

title: Secretary of State Pompeo visits University of Louisville
summary:
LOUISVILLE, Ky. (AP) — U.S. Secretary of State Mike Pompeo says some Latin American nations are taking a “sharp turn toward democracy, capitalism and good government” in an address at the University of Louisville.
Pompeo was visiting Monday ahead of a trip to London for a NATO summit with President Trump.
Pompeo was invited to speak by Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell as part of the university’s McConnell Center lecture series.
Pompeo mentioned a Kentucky connection, saying he was stationed at Fort Knox while serving in the military.
He spoke briefly and answered a few questions posed by McConnell.

More than 50 works by Picasso never seen in America now on display at Louisville's KMAC
summary:
CLOSEMore than 50 works by Pablo Picasso never seen outside of Europe are now on display at KMAC in downtown Louisville.
Sponsored by UPS, "Picasso: From Antibes to Louisville" brings together 52 ceramics and works on paper created by Picasso between 1931 and 1956.
KMAC is spread over three levels, with the Picasso exhibit on the second floor.
Dec. 20, 2019 (Photo: Scott Utterback/Courier Journal )KMAC Museum is the contemporary art museum in downtown Louisville's Museum Row and its goal is to educate and inspire while promoting a better understanding of art through exhibitions, education and collections.

title: It's going to be a wild ride: Farmers’ Almanac predicts a 'Polar Coaster' this winter
summary:
CLOSE Farmers' Almanac predicts a "polar coaster" of a winter The News JournalWhat if we take a different approach to the weather this winter?
"We're calling this winter a 'Polar Coaster' because of fluctuating warm and cold temperatures and precipitation," Peter Geiger, editor of the 200-year-old Farmers’ Almanac publication, told the Courier Journal.
The Farmers’ Almanac bases its long-range forecast for the United States "on a mathematical and astronomical formula developed in 1818."
Farmer's Almanac (Photo: Farmer's Almanac)Be prepared: How to keep your pipes from freezing this winter in KentuckyYou'll need a coat at Kentucky DerbyThis year's winter will cause a slow start to a spring season, according to the Farmers' Almanac.
While the Farmers' Almanac offers little rest for the winter-weary this year, there is a positive spin to this season's outlook.
